Articles.Content: hi i am trying to learn how to dock. i have done the in game tutorial but when i tried it in my career mode, and when i burn retrograde to slow down my interception node changes. is there a way to avoid this?

The in-game tutorial is seriously borked-- obsolete, hasn't been updated in a long time-- so it's likely to cause you some confusion if you try to use it.  They're giving it a major overhaul in the upcoming 1.1 release, should be a lot more straightforward then.

Docking consists of two major steps:

  1. Rendezvous:  setting up an orbit that will take you close by the target (e.g. within a kilometer or two).
  2. Docking:  bringing yourself to a halt right next to the target, then getting your docking port lined up and connecting to it.

These two things involve somewhat different skills and techniques.  Which one are you having trouble with?

If you can get a reasonable rendezvous (i.e. get yourself on a path that will pass within a couple of kilometers of the target), then here's an illustrated docking tutorial I put together that will take you through the steps from there. Hopefully you may find it useful.

There are also a lot of other tutorials floating around out there that various folks have put together (including how to set up a rendezvous, which my tutorial doesn't cover); some googling should turn them up.

The rendezvous part is covered very nicely in this tutorial from the KSP Reddit page. 

https://www.reddit.com/r/KerbalSpaceProgram/comments/29qjgm/illustrated_tutorial_for_orbital_rendezvous/

It doesn't show the absolute most efficient way to do it, but it's good for describing the effects of different types of burns to get your obits to match. 

Edited February 4, 2016 by FullMetalMachinist

19 hours ago, pingell1 said:

hi i am trying to learn how to dock. i have done the in game tutorial but when i tried it in my career mode, and when i burn retrograde to slow down my interception node changes. is there a way to avoid this?  

Hi Pingel - I note you say that when you slow down to match your target's velocity (and therefore, orbit) your interception node moves. This would suggest your manoeuvres are either at the wrong time, or in the wrong order.

Essentially, to successfully dock, you firstly need to successfully rendezvous.

And doing that is, boiled down, a two step process:

1) Plan a manoeuvre (probably far away from your target/intercept point) such that the map predicts a very, very close point of intercept - ideally with a separation of less than 0.5km

2) Make the burn to achieve that intercept.  Once you have arrived 500m (or less) away from your target vessel, then you match your velocity to theirs - essentially putting you on the same orbit as them. And, if you're in the same orbit and at (nearly) the same point in space you will have (nearly) zero relative velocity - and will have 'parked' next to them.

The important point here, and this sounds like where you may be going wrong, is that your 'slow down' burn needs to happen after you've intercepted the target vessel so you relative velocities are reduced to zero at the same point in space (nearly) where you both are at the same time. - Not during your intercept but at the intercept.

(this is why it can help to be in a relatively similar shaped orbit to start with so that when you converge you're not travelling in wildly different velocities).

Wemb

Edited February 5, 2016 by Wemb

On ‎2‎/‎4‎/‎2016 at 9:05 AM, pingell1 said:

hi i am trying to learn how to dock. i have done the in game tutorial but when i tried it in my career mode, and when i burn retrograde to slow down my interception node changes. is there a way to avoid this?  

Not really.  When you create and fiddle with maneuver nodes on the map, the predicted path you see is under the assumption that the burn happens instantaneously precisely at the node.  Problem is, burns actually take a measurable amount of time to perform, so you generally do half the burn before and the other half after you pass the node.  When your ship is burning but not exactly at the point of the node, it's aimed a bit off of the prograge or retrograde direction, which means a bit of the thrust is actually being applied along the radial inwards or outwards direction.  Radial burns rotate the positions of your Ap and Pe on your orbit relative to where they are now.  This necessarily changes the angle of your flightpath slightly from what was originally predicted when you placed the node.  Therefore, if you create a node to intercept a target and the predicted closest approach distance is X, after you do the burn, the distance will actually turn out to be Y, somewhat different from X.  But you should still be close enough for government work.

The difference between the pre-burn predicted closest approach and the post-burn actual closest approach is minimized when there's not a big difference in the orbital altitudes of you and your target.  Still, even a 100-200km difference in altitudes shouldn't throw you off very much.  Even being a few km away from the target when you match speeds is pretty easy to fix by burning directly at the target to so you close in a 30-50m/s until you get a lot closer.
